Institutional racism in Britain’s universities is harming the performance of minority ethnic students, the UK’s first professor of black studies has said.

Kehinde Andrews, an associate professor at Birmingham City University (BCU), told a conference last week marking Black History Month that universities are “no less institutionally racist than the police”, and criticised the curriculum for being overly “white”.

“Universities produce racism,” Andrews told the Guardian. “It’s only since the 1960s there have been any black or Asian people – or women – at all.” In the intervening decades, little has happened to challenge ingrained attitudes and approaches, he said. “Are universities producing knowledge that challenges racism? I would argue that they are not.”

Last year a report by the Runnymede Trust, an equalities thinktank, warned that universities had proved “remarkably resilient to change in terms of curriculum, culture and staffing, remaining for the most part ‘ivory towers’ − with the emphasis on ‘ivory’”.

Speaking after his comments at the Black History Month event were reported by the Sunday Times, Andrews said there had been a persistent “attainment gap” between white and non-white students, even among ethnic minorities that tend to perform well at school.

“Something’s happening in those three or four years of education to institute the gap,” he said.

Three-quarters of white students achieve a 2:1 degree or higher, compared to 60% of minority ethnic students. This is the same at universities up and down the league table, he said.

“Somewhere like Oxford or Cambridge, you might expect people to feel marginalised and excluded: there’s very few minority students. But actually at BCU 50% of students are ethnic minority … You might think surely it wouldn’t be the same as in Cambridge. But you still have exactly the same situation,” he said.

“There’s obviously something about what’s happening in the way things are organised and the way things are run … it’s institutional. It’s beyond an individual place or act.”

Related: Marlon James calls for action on diversity instead of just talk

Andrews believes the curriculum is a key factor. In his own discipline – sociology – the canon taught as the foundation of the subject is “a collection of dead white men”, he said. “And that’s the same at every university.”

He is not alone with these concerns. Last year, the National Union of Students backed a student campaign, “Why is my curriculum white”, highlighting the lack of diversity in the texts assigned to students, prompting discussions within some of the UK’s top universities on the issue.

At Cambridge, academics are running a research group on “decolonising the curriculum”. One of the group’s organisers, African politics lecturer Adam Branch, told the Guardian that this aims to acknowledge the colonial roots of many of the institutions and approaches that make up a university.

The decolonising approach examines how this affects universities today, “from what texts are read, to who is admitted, employed, and promoted, to the relation between the university and the community, to what knowledge is valued and what is dismissed or ignored,” Branch said.

Andrews says that in humanities subjects, which are largely self-guided, the impact of studying authors who not only fail to interest but sometimes “actually alienate” students can harm their education. “So if you’re reading Kant and Kant’s talking about European enlightenment and talking down about Africa and the rest of the world … it’s really difficult to get into that stuff.”

The most glaring illustrations of racial inequality in universities is in their staffing, Andrews said: just 60 of the UK’s 14,000 professors are black.

Related: Students don’t mind studying dead white men, but they want dead women too

“It’s unbelievable it’s that bad. And that’s not just at redbrick universities – it’s replicated across the entire sector,” he said.

Minority ethnic staff frequently experience micro-aggressions – small acts of discrimination, Andrews said. “I get this all the time. In my first job I went to go to a staff part of the university and someone put their hands physically on me and pushed me out of the room – they had assumed I must be a student.”

He described how he adopts a “dress code” of smarter shoes and trousers whenever he goes on to campus, after persistently being questioned by security guards early in his career. “It’s at the point where if I’m near university dressed like I would normally dress, if I have to go into university I will always go home and get changed, just because if I don’t I will get hassled,” he said.

Andrews is currently working on a paper counting how many black sociologists are permanently employed in the UK. “I’ve so far counted 15 – and that includes the five sociologists at BCU. Outside of BCU you’re very unlikely to see a black sociologist anywhere in the UK and that must be caused by institutional racism: I don’t have any other explanation,” he said.

Tutankhamun (ITV) | ITV Hub

As if America didn’t have enough to contend with, in Paxman on Trump v Clinton: Divided America, Jeremy Paxman travelled to the US to ask: “What on earth has happened to a truly great democracy that the choice is so awful?” Post-Brexit, any critique of another nation’s calamity could seem more than a tad “Pot.Kettle.Black”. However, Paxman was on fine form, as though spraying linguistic lava from a permanently erupting volcano. “This year’s presidential election has shaped up rather like a reality TV contest,” he scoffed. Later, of Donald Trump’s ascendance: “Many conservatives still thought he was a spiv wearing spray-tan Republicanism.”

The documentary made a goodish fist of impartiality, with references to Hillary’s emails, her “deplorables” outburst, the fact that she’s a Clinton and the embodiment of the “political class” (“Hillary reeks of Washington”) and everything else that apparently turns off “angry white voters” so much that they would rather elect a sexist, racist, narcissistic halfwit with hair like demonically possessed candyfloss and the political acumen of a deep-fried whoopee cushion.

However, while Clinton’s toxicity was dealt with (some disaffected Bernie Sanders supporters prefer to vote for Trump), Paxman reserved his main scalpel cuts for a non-anaesthetised dissection of the Trump phenomenon. Washington strategist Jim Messina related how he’d initially prayed for the Republican nominee to be Trump, as he’d be the “easiest to beat”. The irony was not lost on Paxman, who stood by the grave of the acerbic commentator HL Mencken, paraphrasing his line: “On some great and glorious day, the plain folks of the land will reach their heart’s desire at last and the White House will be adorned by a downright moron.” Quite. And, if the most recent televised debate is anything to go by, a “downright moron” who will not necessarily accept a losing result.

The documentary ended as it began, with America poised on a slippery, unedifying electoral precipice, being jabbed urgently with a comedy stick with a boxing glove stuck on the end, perchance with ashen-faced British viewers feebly wailing at the screen: “Don’t do it, America, don’t be as stupid as we were!” At least there was amusement in Paxman’s (post-“grab them by the pussy”) interview with Trump’s new bestie, Nigel Farage. Farage backed away from Trump so fast that if smell-o-vision had been available, my living room would have been filled with the stench of burning rubber.

When the US award-winning sitcom Black-ish was first broadcast in 2014, Trump tweeted: “Can you imagine the furor [sic] of a show [called] ‘Whiteish’! Racism at highest level?” Erm, more racist than a wall to keep out Mexicans and a ban on Muslims? We’ll have to get back to Trump on that one.

Now being aired here week-nightly on E4, from the pilot episode onwards, Black-ish, created by Kenya Barris, more than deserves its reputation as the funny show that tackles race issues head on. Anthony Anderson plays Dre Johnson, father of an upper-middle-class black family, with a mixed-race doctor wife, Rainbow, played by Tracee Ellis Ross (“I’m not really black? Could somebody tell my hair and my ass?”), deadpan grandad, played by Laurence Fishburne (“I can smell a group hug coming on”), and the requisite brood of cute, wisecracking kids.

Perhaps the curse of the pharaohs still lingers because the dialogue in Tutankhamun was shocking

I wasn’t sure what to expect (a black Modern Family?), but Black-ish’s strengths soon emerged in its confident vision, whip-smart writing and knowing absurdist flourishes, such as a sightseeing tour driving past the Anderson abode: “If you look to your left, you’ll see the mythical and majestic black family, out of their natural habitat and yet still thriving.”

Later episodes will deal with everything from racist language to police brutality, but the pilot mainly focused on the challenges of the family’s blended (black-ish) reality. Pilot episodes can be clunky, and Black-ish was no exception, with an overzealous “on-message” feel. However, by the second episode it was hitting its stride, with a defiantly silly parental sex talk theme. Meanwhile, grandad advised his eldest granddaughter about some peer group problems, later telling Rainbow: “I listened to her, gave her some generic advice in a deep soothing voice – I ‘Morgan Freeman-ed’ her.”

Tutankhamun appears to have been conceived for the ITV Sunday night slot still haunted by the ratings ghost of Downton Abbey. There’s even a Downton link in that Sam Neill plays the fifth Earl of Carnarvon (of Highclere Castle, where Downton was filmed), the patron of Howard Carter (Max Irons), who’s hunting for the Egyptian boy king’s final resting place as the first world war breaks out.

Perhaps the curse of the pharaohs still lingers because the dialogue was shocking: “If he’s out there, he’s waited 3,000 years; I believe he can wait a bit longer.” Apart from Irons’s fling with Catherine Steadman’s American archaeologist (“married to her work”), the main excitement was provided by the unearthing of a mug that supposedly belonged to Tutankhamun but which rather resembled ancient Tupperware from the lost city of Argos. Ultimately, Tutankhamun was pleasant enough, a kind of underpowered sand-and-trowel affair, but it won’t be enough to bury BBC rival Poldark.

One of my all-time favourite films is Brian De Palma’s Carrie, so I was intrigued by the opener to the three-part supernatural thriller Him, written by Paula Milne (The Politician’s Husband, The Night Watch). The eponymous, otherwise unnamed Him, ably portrayed by Fionn Whitehead, is a troubled, truanting, spliff-smoking 17-year-old whose telekinetic powers (from tying shoelaces with no hands to exploding water tanks) give him nosebleeds. His situation is exacerbated by the disappointing, warring adults surrounding him, most notably his divorced parents (tensely portrayed by Katherine Kelly and James Murray) and their hostile new partners (Lucy Liemann and Patrick Robinson).

Like any telekinetic drama worth its salt, Him centres on adolescent misery, isolation, fury and sundry other powerful emotions: Him was seen falling for his stepsister (Simona Brown), whose voiceover runs through the tale. There were times when it all got a bit too daft (sharp tools hovered Tom and Jerry-style above the stepfather’s unwitting head), but I, for one, rather enjoyed the novelty of it all. The performances were universally strong, and there was a determined sense of artistry to Andy De Emmony’s direction, birds flocking in the skies with Hitchcockian menace. The first episode climaxed with Him becoming aware of the dark potential of his powers and not seeming all that upset about it. If I were one of the parents, I’d be considering confiscating any school prom tickets.
